content: It's not easy, if your hours fall outside the normal "seven to five" that most child care centers cover. It's also tough when you get CQ or any kind of a field assignment - those can last a few weeks. You'll also have to go to courses lasting a few weeks at various times in your career, to say nothing of deployments. Trying to find childcare to cover all of these situations won't be easy. If you do keep your kids with you, their school will be disrupted if you have to ship them home every time you have a training course lasting just a few weeks. Just so you're aware before you go into it.

Custody is more serious than transfering a title to a pickup truck. In most cases it's binding and non-revokeable. The father has a superior right to the children than does your parents. He is in the position to object to this plan and seek sole custody if you voluntarily enlist. If custody is transferred, there is no guarantee you will get them back. The laws of your state take precedence over what a recruiter assures you. Thread carefully and become aware of all consequences. Stop by your local Family Court and seek professional guidance.

They will be the ones to sign the custody forms required to join the military. the only thing my ex will have is visitation rights. I have everything in writing. Custody is more serious than transfering a title to a pickup truck. In most cases it's binding and non-revokeable. The father has a superior right to the children than does your parents. He is in the position to object to this plan and seek sole custody if you voluntarily enlist. If custody is transferred, there is no guarantee you will get them back. The laws of your state take precedence over what a recruiter assures you. Thread carefully and become aware of all consequences. Stop by your local Family Court and seek professional guidance.
